This review discusses the application of DFT in SCR research from the aspects of surface adsorption, active site characteristics, reaction mechanism, poisoning mechanism, and hydrothermal aging mechanism to illustrate the status of quantum chemical computing in this field. The gas adsorption includes the adsorption of nitrogen oxides, ammonia, and their co-adsorption. As an important atmospheric pollutant, NO x has been attracting much attention at home and abroad. Especially after officially entering the national VI stage, the emission of pollutants has been significantly reduced compared with the national V stage [2], which poses a huge challenge to the automobile enterprises and catalyst manufacturers. Ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) technology is the most widely used means for NO x removal today, and its core lies in the catalyst. In order to find SCR catalysts with higher catalytic efficiency, wider reaction temperature window, better low-temperature activity, and hydrothermal stability, many scholars have made great efforts. From low-cost vanadium-based oxides [3] to copper zeolite catalysts with excellent activity and hydrothermal stability [4,5], as well as various oxides [6,7], precious metals and other types of zeolite catalysts [8], the relevant research on SCR catalysts involves all aspects in the field of physics, chemistry, and materials [9]. In view of the different components and materials of catalysts, their preparation, characterization, and the reaction mechanism have been extensively and meticulously researched. There have been many means of testing to characterize the chemical and physical properties of catalysts on various aspects, such as the BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) testing method (applied to characterize the specific surface area of the catalysts), the X-ray crystal diffraction (X-ray diffraction, XRD) method (applied to characterize the crystal structure of catalysts), the inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) method (applied to test the element composition and content of catalysts), and the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) technique (applied to characterize the surface chemical properties of catalysts). The H2-TPR (temperature-programmed reduction) experiment is used to test the redox performance of metal elements in catalysts, and the in situ diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy (In-situ DRIFTS) is used to study the information of intermediate species and catalysts structure in the process of catalytic reaction. The microscopic morphology, crystal phase structure, and elemental composition of the catalysts can all be illustrated by physical and chemical characterization. Combined with the experimental test results, we can clarify the active components in the catalysts, the path and mechanism of the SCR reaction. These research results undoubtedly provide a huge reference value and theoretical basis for the design and development of new generation catalysts. In addition to the experimental methods, the theoretical calculation method of molecular simulation, especially the density functional theory (DFT), is also widely used in the study of SCR catalysts. On the one hand, the theoretical calculation can be used as a supplement to the experimental study, and the mutual verification with the experimental results improves the credibility of the experiment. With the development of quantum chemistry, DFT has been widely used in various molecular and atomic systems to analyze the physical and chemical properties of the system and then the information of chemical reactivity, catalytic activity, photophysical properties and NMR spectrums can be obtained [10]. On the other hand, the theoretical calculation results of molecular simulation can well explain experimental phenomena, predict the properties of specific materials, reveal the influence of catalyst surface characteristics on the reaction process and the occurrence mechanism of SCR reaction from the micro-scale, which accelerates the birth of new theoretical achievements [11]. As a supplement of experimental study, molecular simulation method in this field has obtained the good effects in the study of the oxidation, deactivation and modification of catalysts. The molecular simulation method is highly efficient, and at the same time, we can also obtain information that is difficult to find in a large number of experiments, which would help to modify existing catalysts and develop new catalysts. In this paper, from the aspects of surface adsorption, reaction mechanism, poisoning mechanism, hydrothermal aging mechanism, and catalyst modification in SCR reaction process, the necessity and important role of DFT in the research field of SCR catalyst were explained, and some opinions and suggestions on the application and development of DFT were put forward. 2 Molecular simulation calculations and density function theory The rapid development of computer technology provides a new direction and method for the study of solid materials. Based on classical mechanics and quantum mechanics theory, the molecular simulation methods mainly include molecular mechanics methods, quantum mechanics methods and their combination methods. Based on the existing knowledge and theory, the microcosmic model of the system is established, and then the structure and properties of the system at the molecular and atomic levels are obtained based on certain algorithms [12]. The method of molecular mechanics is based on the interaction between atoms. The calculation starts from the force field between atoms. The accuracy of the simulation depends on the choice of force field. The molecular mechanics method is fast and can deal with large atomic systems. The quantum mechanics method is based on the interaction between electrons outside the nucleus, and the Schrodinger equation can be solved by some approximate processing to obtain more accurate results. The quantum mechanics method has a large amount of calculation and a slow calculation speed, and can only be used to deal with small atomic systems, but it can accurately predict the structure, energy and catalytic mechanism of the system [13]. Since the 1980s, the newly developed DFT takes the electron density as the basic physical quantity, and gradually replaces the ab initio algorithm and the semi-empirical algorithm which take the wave function as the basic physical quantity. DFT can be used to study the related properties of molecules and atoms, such as calculation of ionization potential, activation energy, selection of catalytic active sites, etc. DFT is based on the further development of traditional experimental research. It cannot be separated from the support of experimental data, but it can also provide information that can't be obtained only through experiments. At the same time, it verifies the correctness of experimental results and gives full play to its practical value, which is of great significance for the synthesis and improvement of catalysts. DFT is a complete set of quantum mechanics models and methods, can be used to calculate a variety of different materials and systems, the current mainstream DFT calculation tools including VASP, CP2K, Gaussian, CASTEP, etc. Molecular and atomic models of catalysts with different elemental components and microstructure can be built. Common models include cluster model, layered embedding model and periodicity model, etc. Different models are suitable for different research contents and objects, and the choice of computing methods should also be considered. DFT has become a general method to describe the properties of substances from the micro-scale. For catalysts with different composition, structure and performance, we can use DFT to obtain effective and reliable information and explore the SCR processes. The vanadium oxide catalysts are cheap and of good sulfur resistance, but they also have some defects such as narrow temperature window and toxicity [14], there are many researches on vanadium-based catalysts. From the construction of atomic model to the exploration of related chemical reactions, DFT has played a great role in the study and improvement of their properties [15,16]. In order to overcome the defect of narrow temperature window of vanadium-based catalyst, it has always been a goal and challenge to find SCR catalysts with wide temperature window, especially with good low temperature activity. In addition to precious metal catalysts, catalysts containing transition metals have also been the research object of many researchers. Due to the variable valence state and excellent redox performance, the Mn-based catalyst has good low temperature catalytic activity, which is explained by the combination of experimental characterization, kinetic simulation study and DFT [17]. As a hot research object in the field of catalysis in recent years, zeolites have a unique spatial configuration. For their special pore structure and active site, DFT is a very suitable description and research method. Both iron zeolites [18] with excellent high temperature hydrothermal stability and copper zeolites represented by Cu-SSZ-13 and Cu-SAPO-34 with excellent catalytic activity and wide temperature window [19] have been studied by DFT. In the modification of catalysts, such as the improvement of various properties by adding rare earth elements [20], the study of sulfur resistance and hydrothermal stability of catalysts [21], DFT is not hindered by the complexity of the research process and the diversity of the research objects, and provides a new way for the study of complex processes and the elucidation of the mechanism. 3 Research on scr based on dft 3.1 Surface adsorption SCR belongs to gas-solid multiphase reaction, adsorption process is a key step of SCR reaction, so the research of gas molecules adsorption process on catalysts surface is helpful to understand the catalytic activity of catalysts and reaction mechanism [22]. Experimental method and quantum chemical methods can be used to study the SCR reaction adsorption process. The bond length, bond angle and energy information obtained by DFT can often be used to verify the results of spectral analysis, TPD, TPR and reaction kinetics [23-25]. Based on different research perspectives and methods, we can get closer to the essence of matter from many aspects. In the process of SCR reaction, the gasses involved are mainly NH3, NO x and O2, etc. When the catalyst is in different atmospheres, the adsorption conditions of gasses are often different. Focusing on the adsorption process of one certain gas, and further studying the co-adsorption of two or more gasses can obtain the key information of the interaction between gas molecules and catalysts, thus providing a basis for the subsequent study of the whole reaction [26]. The information of adsorption process can be obtained by calculating the model of crystal cell or atomic cluster, and then the site of adsorption, the intensity of adsorption and the intermediate species produced during adsorption can be inferred. 3.1.1 NO adsorption By calculating the adsorption of NO on the surface of the catalyst, we can obtain a lot of information about the surface characteristics of the catalyst. Kornelak et al. [27] studied the NO adsorption on the reduced surfaces of V2O5 and V2O5 with Mo defects. Their calculations were performed using LCGTO-DFT program DeMon. Double-zeta valence basis sets with polarization functions (DZVP) were used for all the atoms in the all-electron calculations. They found that the adsorption of NO on the surface of the surface-reduced clusters has a higher adsorption energy, but the defect structure formed by replacing a V atom with a Mo had almost no effect on the surface adsorption of NO, that is, this substitution would not enhance or weaken the adsorption capacity of NO. Their research explains to a certain extent the adsorption characteristics of NO on the surface of vanadium-based catalysts. For the NO adsorption on the surface of the manganese-based catalyst, Fang et al. [28] conducted adsorption and activation of NO on CuMn2O4 and NiMn2O4 catalysts supported by TiO2. The generalized gradient approximation according to PW91 was employed. They systematically calculated the adsorption on the surfaces (3 1 1) and (1 1 1) of CuMn2O4 and NiMn2O4. The adsorption energies of NO on the CuMn2O4 (1 1 1) surface and NiMn2O4 (1 1 1) surface are 2.40 eV and 1.26 eV, respectively, which are both stable adsorption forms. The lone pair of electrons of the N atom forms a bond with the Mn atom. On other hand, the length of the NO bond of adsorbed NO is slightly longer than that of the free NO bond, and the adsorption energy of NO on CuMn2O4 (3 1 1) surface and NiMn2O4 (3 1 1) surface are 1.73 eV and 1.85 eV, respectively. That is, the adsorption of NO on the (1 1 1) surface and (3 1 1) surface is obviously different. As for the (3 1 1) plane has a more complicated chemical environment than the (1 1 1) plane, and it will even cause the tilt of the adsorbed NO molecules, showed in Fig. 1 . The amount of absorbed NO on Ni-Mn/TiO2 is larger than that of Cu-Mn/TiO2, which is consistent with the phenomenon observed experimentally. Their calculations show that adsorption has a great relationship with crystal plane orientation and element composition. Not only is it related to the nature of the adsorption surface itself, the adsorption of NO on the surface of other oxide catalysts such as MgO and γ-Al2O3 will also be affected by the composition of the atmosphere. For example, H2 will promote the adsorption of NO x at low temperatures, and C3H6 will hinder the adsorption of NO x , and NH3 has no effect on the adsorption of NO x in general [29]. Than taking the adsorption of NO on copper zeolite catalyst as an example, Zhang et al. [30] studied the chemisorption process of NO on Cu-SSZ-13 by using DFT calculation and infrared spectrum analysis. A trapezohexahedral crystal cell containing 12 T sites and 24 oxygen atoms and PW91 exchange correlation were selected for DFT calculation in VASP (Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package). The calculation results of density of state in Fig. 2 clearly determine the two coordination structures of copper atom and lattice oxygen atom, and then determine the different oxidation states of copper atom under three coordination and four coordination. The adsorption structure in Fig. 3 vividly describes the adsorption of NO under these two coordination structures. According to DFT calculation results of vibration frequency and adsorption energy combined with the FTIR test results, it can be found that the bond between NO and [Cu(OH)]+ in the eight-membered ring is much stronger than that of isolated Cu2+ in the six-membered ring. The experimental results in Table 1 are in perfect agreement with the calculated results, indicating that there are three kinds of chemisorbed species coexisting in NO under dehydration and high vacuum conditions: NO+, Cu2+-NO and Cu+-NO, and the relative signal strength of these three kinds of chemical bonds is greatly affected by the Si/Al ratio. The vibration frequency analysis can be used to verify the results of experimental spectral analysis, which greatly increases the credibility of the work. Also by VASP calculations, Anggara et al. [31] used the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) method and hybrid functional method to calculate the adsorption of NO x on Cu-SSZ-13. They respectively using the periodic SSZ-13 cell model and the modified cluster model, reached similar conclusions: NO x and isolate the copper ion bonding may not change the copper ion valence state, it is possible to oxidize monovalent copper to divalent copper, which is consistent with the experimental observations. Combining the calculation process, the selection of the calculation method of evaluation and calculation model, although GGA method when calculating the structure is more reliable in the general case, but once involving the NO x in response of energy change, GGA method can tend to overestimate the adsorption of certain species, especially in the calculation of copper ion adsorption results when the two species were significantly overstated. Therefore, whether to choose the GGA approximation or the hybrid functional method still needs to depend on the actual situation, there is no invariable general calculation method, and we can get closer to the truth by constantly trying and adjusting. 3.1.2 NH3 adsorption In addition to studying the adsorption of NO on the surface of CuMn2O4 and NiMn2O4 catalysts, Fang et al. [28] also conducted adsorption and activation of NH3 on CuMn2O4 and NiMn2O4 catalysts supported by TiO2. The adsorption model of NO was compared with that of NH3, and they found that the adsorption of NO was stronger than that of NH3 and their preferred adsorption sites were different. PDOS analysis showed that adsorption could reduce the energy of the adsorbed substance, that is, the adsorption process might be spontaneous. NH3 on the catalyst surface adsorption and subsequent SCR reaction are closely linked, for example, Anstrom et al. [32] obtained V2O5 crystal structure parameters from experiments and then build the V4 clusters model, the model chose V2O5 (0 1 0) plane of four vanadium atom, as well as directly connected with all the oxygen atom bonding, finally used hydrogen atoms to saturate. They used NH3 molecules as a probe to study the adsorption process after the structure optimization, as shown in Fig. 4 . They selected B3LYP as the exchange correlation functional, and used the LACVP ** basis set to treat metal V atoms, and 6–31G** basis set to treat H, O, and N atoms to calculate the adsorption energy and transition state energy of cluster model when SCR reaction occurs. By calculating the properties of V4O16H12, they found that the stable adsorption of NH3 occurred between the two V = O bonds to form NH4 species. Then, NO also adsorbs on the surface and binds to NH3 molecule. Two nitrogen atoms bond to form an intermediate species, NH3NHO. Then, NH3NHO breaks off two H atoms to generate the key intermediate product, NH2NO, as shown in Fig. 5 . Finally, NH2NO decomposes into N2 and H2O to complete the denitrification process. The reduction of vanadium oxide clusters is accomplished by the "push-pull" transfer of hydrogen atoms from the catalyst surface to the NH2NO species. Similarly, Liu et al. [33] constructed a larger V8O20H4 atomic group to study the active site, simulated the physical adsorption and chemical adsorption processes of NH3 on the surface of this group. The exchange-correlation functional was calculated via Perdew-Wang-1991 generalized-gradient approximation (PW91, GGA). Double numerical basis was set using P-orbital polarization function for atom figuring. Combined with experimental means, they speculated the role of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites in SCR reaction. They respectively established V2O5 (0 0 1) periodic cluster models containing 100% Lewis acid sites and 50% Lewis and 50% Brønsted acid sites, and then simulated the adsorption of NH3, as shown in Fig. 6 . They believed that above 300 °C, hydrogen migration calculated by DFT and the presence of intermediate species NH2 confirmed the role of Lewis acid site in SCR reaction. It is further explained that Lewis acid plays a greater role at high temperature, while Brønsted acid site plays a greater role at low temperature, that is, the intensity of oxidation reaction and reduction reaction is largely affected by temperature, as shown in Fig. 7 . Although the above clusters containing 4 and 8 V atoms cannot accurately describe the structural characteristics of the whole catalyst system, they can accurately simulate the local structure around active V atoms, and these models are applicable to small atomic clusters. In the small system, it's easier to observe the atomic position. DFT in the study of atomic migration and the formation and rupture of key chemical bonds has played a key role, and then we can find the transition state and the key intermediate species of the SCR reaction mechanism. Finally, we would confirm rate-determining step of reaction and form a complete redox reaction cycle. 3.1.3 Co-adsorption When the actual SCR reaction occurs, far more than one gas is adsorbed, and the occurrence of co-adsorption varies greatly with the different catalysts. Here, we pay much attention to the co-adsorption of NH3 and NO x in the SCR reaction process, taking the co-adsorption of Mn-based catalyst as an example. Xiang et al. [34] used Materials Studio (MS) DMol3 module to calculate the adsorption characteristic of MNO2 and Mn2O3 catalysts loaded on γ-Al2O3. They chose PW91 exchange relevant functional and double-number rail base with polarization function group (DNP). Their results show that NO can realize stable adsorption to form nitrite or nitrosyl species on both of them. When loading MNO2, NH3 is adsorbed on Al and Mn atomic sites in the form of ligands. When loading Mn2O3, NH3 is also adsorbed in the form of ligand, but it may also be dissociated into H and -NH2 groups at the adjacent positions of Mn2O3 and the surface of the carrier. The above studies are typical cases in which DFT is used to compare the strength and spontaneity of the adsorption capacity of gasses and to judge the adsorption sites on catalysts. The determination of the adsorption situation can directly determine the direction of subsequent chemical reactions. Zhang et al. [35] studied the adsorption mechanism of NO and NH3 molecules on Mn3O4/TiO2 surface by DFT and experimental methods. They selected the TiO2 superlattice layer structure as the carrier, the repeated unit of Mn3O4 crystal cell as active component, periodic boundary conditions, using PW91 with polarization functions and functional numerical basis set to calculate the related parameters such as adsorption, bond length and local density of states. The results of NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid and Brønsted acid are shown in Table 2 . It was found that the nitrogen oxides were first adsorbed on the manganese terminal to form nitrate, and NH3 was more easily adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site. NH4 + is formed when ammonia and water molecules exist at the same time, this is due to the adsorption and dissociation of water molecules on the catalyst surface is the main source of hydroxyl groups, indicating that l-H mechanism plays a major role. Although chemical reactions are very complex, there are a variety of pathways and reaction mechanisms, elementary reactions are countless, we can rule out the impossible results from the known results, infer a reliable reaction path, which is also a major application of DFT. For other different types of catalysts, DFT can achieve the same effects. For example, when NH3 and NO are adsorbed on CuAl2O4 (100), Cu2+ is the most ideal adsorption site, and NO is easier to adsorb than NH3 [36]. In Fe+-SSZ-13 zeolite, the adsorption status of H2O, OH and O on the Fe site in the six-membered ring and the eight-membered ring is basically similar, and the OH group can promote the adsorption of NO at the eight-membered ring Fe2+, but not for Fe3+ [37]. There are also some other interesting phenomena, such as Cu+ in the eight-member ring of copper zeolite would migrate during the co-adsorption of NH3 and H2O, and its coordination number and ligand are affected by temperature and gas environment [38]. Using DFT to obtain the adsorption process of structure and energy information, calculate the vibration information of specific adsorption structure could verify the experimental results. Different from experimental methods, DFT theoretical calculations can reveal the microscopic mechanism of reactions at the atomic level, which is not available by experimental methods alone. It is also difficult to calculate the reactive adsorption energy and determine the characteristic information of adsorption sites by experimental methods. All the theoretical calculation results in the above study are in good agreement with the experimental results, which further demonstrates the feasibility of using DFT calculation method to study the SCR reaction mechanism. 3.2 Active site characteristics and reaction mechanisms Active site is the key position to play a catalytic role, we often use DFT to study the related properties of the catalyst surface active sites, the analysis of gas molecules on the surface of the catalyst, behavioral changes, and then study the coordination and interaction between gas molecules and the active sites, such research explains the prerequisite of the SCR catalytic reactions. More deeply, we can still simulate the key intermediate species and predict transition state, to analyze the structures and properties of intermediate species in the whole path, eventually we would complete the mechanism of SCR reaction. These studies deepen our understanding of different catalysts and SCR reaction mechanism. 3.2.1 The activation of no In the study of SCR reaction mechanism, we pay much attention to the behavior change of gas molecules on the surface of catalyst. Such behavior change can directly indicate the interaction ability of gas molecules and catalysts, and reveal the performance of catalysts to a certain extent. The activation of NO on the surface of the catalyst is a key step of SCR reaction, and this step would be greatly affected by catalytic conditions. For vanadium-based catalysts, the interaction of NO and vanadium sites runs through the entire redox cycle of the SCR reaction [39], Koebel et al. proved that NO2 can oxidize V4+ to V5+to promote the fast SCR reaction [40-42]. In the study of Arnarson et al. [43], they thought NO-activation cycle and a fast SCR cycle share the same reduction part but use NO + O2 and NO2 respectively for the reoxidation. And they found for the NO-activation cycle where O2 is the oxidizing agent the rate is determined by the reoxidation part at low temperatures but the reduction at higher temperatures. Fig. 8 shows the reaction mechanism they proposed for the SCR process, the blue half circle on the left represents the NO-activation cycle. (All calculations were performed with the Grid-based Projector Augmented Wave (GPAW) program with the general gradient approximation (GGA) BEEF-vdW functional.) Chen et al. [44] explored the NO oxidation process on Cu-CHA and Cu-BEA based on the experiments, they thought there were two locations for NO oxidation, which had different effects on the activity of SCR. DFT calculated apparent activation energy can be more intuitive show the difficulty during NO molecular activation. On Brønsted acid sites in the HCHA zeolite, NO oxidation would greatly depend on the temperature conditions. When temperature rose, the apparent activation energy of the NO oxidation would experience from negative to positive, the evolution process of the activation energy of the transition temperature is associated with the replacement atoms of skeleton [45]. The activation of NO at the Cu-CHA zeolite adjacent to copper ions is significantly easier than that at the isolated copper ions, which has also been confirmed by DFT calculation [46]. Through these results, we have more understandings of the special behaviors of gas molecules on the surface of the catalysts. These results can help us to guess the new intermediate species and put forward the new reaction paths. 3.2.2 Position and coordination of the active site Different SCR catalysts have their unique active components, which are reflected as active sites in microstructure. The adsorption, decomposition and other behaviors of gas molecules, as well as the interaction between catalyst and gas molecules tend to take place in this location. Taking copper zeolite catalyst with CHA structure as an example, copper site is the most critical catalytic site, and the active site is easy to change. We can use DFT to determine the distribution and spatial location of the active site, and calculate the coordination structure, electron distribution, valence state and the interaction mechanism with gas molecules at the site. In order to determine the location and coordination characteristics of Cu2+ ions in Cu-SAPO-18, Li et al. [47] calculated the possible locations of Cu2+ ions using DFT based on the EPR results. DFT calculations were performed with the PBE function using VASP. The projector augmented wave method (PAW) was used to describe the interaction between the ions and the electrons with the frozen-core approximation. They simulated 7 possible locations of Cu2+ ions, as shown in Fig. 9 . The relevant energies of optimized structures were calculated, as shown in table. 3 . They deduced the stability of structures is directly related to the distance between Cu2+ ions and two Si atoms in the six-member ring. The Cu2+ ions in structure 1 and structure 6 were the closest to the Si atom in the six-membered ring, and formed bonds with the four oxygen atoms in the six-membered ring, which were the most stable energy states of these seven structures. On the basis of these results they summarized the SCR reaction mechanism on Cu-SAPO-18. The coordination of the active site during SCR reaction is directly related to the occurrence of subsequent SCR reactions. Lezcano-Gonzalez et al. [48] studied the coordination of Cu-SSZ-13 exposed to NO and NH3, respectively. The PBE exchange-correlation functional with additional pairwise dispersion corrections according to the D3 scheme of Grimme in combination with a double-ζ MOLOPT basis set with plane wave cutoff of 300 Ry was used. After the introduction of NO, it can be seen that Cu ions coordinate with two skeletal oxygen and one NO molecule to form a curved Cu-nitrosyl complex with a Cu-N-O bond Angle of about 150° The interaction between NH3 and Cu ions was more intense, and it was likely to generate hexagonal [Cu(NH3)6]2+. These results were of great significance for the absorption and storage of these reactive gasses, and may have an important impact on the mechanism involved in NH3-SCR process. Göltl et al. [49] calculated the coordination phase diagram of Cu+ligand ions and water molecules in SSZ-13 zeolite using the primitive rhombohedral unit cell, periodic boundary conditions by VASP. Combined with the results of spectral analysis, they put forward the defective position of the copper would be migrated from the skeleton, which was helpful to the study of catalyst hydrothermal aging caused by the migration of copper. DFT provides a lot of convenience for studying the location, coordination and migration of copper ions in zeolites, so that we can further explore the properties of active sites of catalysts, and have a deeper understanding of the loss of active sites in the catalytic reaction and catalyst aging process. 3.2.3 Intermediate key species, steps and reaction mechanism In the process of SCR reaction, a series of redox reactions would occur after the interaction between the active site and gas molecules. DFT can be used to confirm the structure of some surface species under SCR condition. Couplet with experiment can further provide help for the improvement of mechanism and kinetics. For the same kind of catalyst, the influence factors of SCR reaction include the environment of gas, reaction temperature, etc. For different reaction conditions we can study the site changes through simulations. McEwen et al. [50] calculated the coordination and oxidation state of Cu+ and Cu2+ under different gas environment in Cu-SSZ-13. Periodic DFT calculations were performed with VASP, a plane wave, supercell DFT code program based on the projector augmented wave (PAW) method. Exchange and correlation were described using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). They put forward the oxidation state of copper are obviously different under the condition of SCR and rapid SCR, which fully embodies the role of copper sites in redox reaction. In Cu-SAPO-34, copper elements with different types and oxidation states also exhibit different catalytic effects [51]. In terms of the influence of temperature on copper oxidation state, Gao et al. [52] found that the SCR rate depended on both the temperature and the oxidation state of copper. All DFT calculations employed a mixed Gaussian and planewave basis sets. The generalized gradient approximation exchange-correlation functional of PBE was used. Through their calculations they proved that isolation Cu+is unable to complete oxidation, the oxidation of the oxygen can only affect [Cu(NH3)2]+ group under low temperature. [Cu(NH3)2]+-O2-[Cu(NH3)2]+ is a key intermediate species in the low temperature oxidation of copper ions. At high temperatures, isolated Cu ions anchor on the SSZ-13 framework and become immobilized. In this case, the oxidation half-cycle occurs on isolated Cu(I) sites with rather high activation barriers. DFT confirmed the reaction is easy to happen, which is consistent with the result of the kinetics of low temperature. [54] found Cu+ in the CHA structure copper zeolite oxidizes to Cu2+ in the presence of NO, O2 and NH3 or NO and O2 at room temperature through EPR and IR spectrums. These results are helpful for the improvement of SCR reaction mechanism on CHA zeolites. A relatively complete vanadium-based SCR mechanism is proposed to explain the rapid SCR and standard SCR reactions. The existence period of intermediate species is very short, especially some transitional structures cannot be observed by experiments. In addition to copper zeolite catalysts, the mechanism of other oxide catalysts can also be studied by DFT [62-64]. 3.3 Poisoning mechanisms The application and working environment of SCR catalyst is sometimes harsh, such as sulfur poisoning caused by sulfur contained in coal burning and fuel oil [65], alkali metal poisoning caused by alkali metal contained in flue gas generated by biomass and coal burning [66], and alkaline earth metal poisoning caused by residual calcium after desulfurization by calcium method [67], etc. Poisoning is an important cause of catalyst deactivation. Exploring the mechanism of catalyst deactivation caused by poisoning is an important topic in SCR research field. The study of catalyst poisoning process by DFT can reveal the change of molecular and atomic structure of catalyst in the poisoning process, and explain the deactivation mechanism of catalyst from the atomic level, which will provide theoretical guidance for the prevention of catalyst poisoning process and the improvement of catalyst performance. 3.3.1 Sulfur poisoning Sulfur poisoning is a problem that cannot be ignored in SCR system of power plant or vehicle, because sulfur poisoning would greatly damage the internal structure and performance of catalyst, and the catalyst deactivation caused by it is often irreversible. Sulfur poisoning is also the most common poisoning phenomenon of SCR catalysts. Sulfur poisoning may exist in vanadium-based catalysts or new zeolite catalysts. Even if the fuel with ultra-low sulfur content (< 15 ppm) is burned, sulfur poisoning would adversely affect the performance of the whole SCR [68]. Zeolites catalysts have good catalytic performance and hydrothermal stability, however, SO2 is easy to interact with the active site on the zeolite to cause the deactivation of the catalyst, which is an important problem that needs to be improved for present zeolite catalysts. There are two kinds of typical active sites on Cu-SSZ-13, they are Z2Cu (six-member ring contains two Al atoms) and ZCuOH (eight-member ring contains an Al atom). The appearance of the two sites is greatly affected by the Si-Al ratio and their related properties are also very different [69]. SO2 has a great influence on the performance of zeolite catalysts and is difficult to regenerate. The effects of SO2 to different copper active sites are very different, which have been proved by experimental methods [70]. On the other hand, the reaction of copper zeolites with SO2 in different atmospheres is different. Wijayanti et al. [71] found that sulfide products included weak combination of SO2 and copper sulfate species during the SO2 poisoning process of Cu-SSZ-13, the existence of water molecule would aggravate the formation of sulfide product, the presence of NH3 molecule leads to the formation of ammonium sulfate, which is the macro mechanism of sulfur poisoning. But we still need to be aware of the micro process of sulfur poisoning, including the changes of copper site deactivation, the degree of deactivation and the vibration information of the energy information structure of the reaction. These information plays a key role in the formation of the whole sulfur poisoning mechanism and is of great significance to the improvement of the sulfur resistance of molecular sieve catalysts. DFT was used to construct an ideal copper active site and simulate its reaction process with SO2, which provided an efficient way to study the mechanism of sulfur poisoning. For the sulfur poisoning of copper zeolites Cu-SSZ-13, Jangjou et al. [72] studied the changes of copper active sites in Cu-SSZ-13 exposed to SO2 gas, and found that SO2 affected Z2Cu and ZCuOH differently at low temperature by in situ DRIFT experiments. They built ZCuOH and dehydrated Z2Cu models and supplemented the characterization results of TPD and DRIFT with DFT calculation. The difference between Z2Cu and ZCuOH sites could be clearly seen from the H2-TPR result and Ex situ DRIFT result in Fig. 13 , and the vibration frequency of DRIFT spectrum was completely in line with the results calculated by DFT. According to the reaction activation energy and enthalpy change calculated by DFT in Table. 4 , it was found that SO2 releases more heat and the activation energy barrier is lower in the ZCuOH model. This indicated that the ZCuOH model absorbs more SO2 than the Z2Cu model to form more sulfites, that is, at low temperatures, the ZCuOH structure was more prone to sulfurization than the Z2Cu structure and finally produces stable sulfates(All calculations were performed using the VASP, and the projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used in conjunction with the Bayesian error estimation functional with van der Waals correction (BEEF-vdW)). In addition to mutual verification and analysis with DRIFT spectrum and TPR results, the combination of the calculation results of DFT with the absorption spectrum of XAS and molecular dynamics simulation can be used to study the skeleton structure, the intermediate of reaction and the migration process of related atomic groups. For example, Shih et al. [73] used DFT to determine the structure of products and intermediates sulfated at ZCuOH and Z2Cu sites as well as the bond energy of bonding. With the help of molecular dynamics simulation (AIMD) module of VASP, they studied the migration process of HSO4 groups, which clarified the sulfur poisoning mechanism of the two sites more clearly. Fig. 14 and 15 show the first-principle phase diagrams of sulfidation at two sites under the same atmosphere. The sulfidation intermediate species are affected by temperature and NH3 partial pressure, and it can be clearly seen that the amount of intermediate products of ZCuOH site is much higher than the Z2Cu site, indicating that ZCuOH is more prone to sulfidation, and the temperature required for catalyst regeneration is higher, which is completely consistent with the experimental results. In addition, the results of molecular dynamics showed that the copper atom connected to one HSO4 group is not easy to move, while the copper atom connected to two HSO4 groups can easily fall off from the zeolite framework, which further explained the reason for sulfur poisoning leading to the loss of active sites of the catalysts. As for the sulfur poisoning of Cu-SAPO-34, the experimental method explains the poisoning mechanism to some extent. Under 210℃, the presence of NH3 is conducive to the adsorption of SO2, and copper sulfate and ammonium sulfate would be generated at the same time, and ammonium sulfate is far more likely to regenerate than copper sulfate. In fact, due to the similar skeleton structure, the sulfur poisoning on Cu-SAPO-34 is similar to Cu-SSZ-13, and the application of DFT perfectly solves this problem. Hammershøi et al. [74] used the projection enhanced wave method based on real spatial grid to explain the van der Waals interaction with BEEF-VDW exchange correlation functional, and calculated the adsorption energy of O2, SO2 and SO3 on copper species in the hexagonal periodic cell of Cu-SAPO-34 to explore the influence of SO2 on Cu-SAPO-34. They added 1.5 ppm SO2 to the SCR reaction at 300 °C and found that SO2 greatly weakened the activity of the catalyst. When the catalyst was regenerated at 550 °C, its reactivity was 80% of the initial value. At 700 °C, the regeneration activity could be completely recovered, which was similar to the decomposition reaction of CuSO4. Therefore, the degree of catalyst deactivation depended on the total amount of SO2 exposure, that is, the product of partial pressure and exposure time. DFT calculation showed that SO2 preferentially binds to Cu+, while SO3 had a stronger binding ability to Cu2+. The adsorption of SO2 and SO3 on Cu-SAPO-34 was in the form of species SO2/Z-Cu+ and SO3/ZCuOH, respectively, as shown in Fig. 16 . There was a large amount of Cu+ below 400 °C, so when NO and NH3 were also present, the absorption rate of SO2 was greatly improved. However, above 400 °C, sulfur absorption decreased with the increase of temperature and was longer affected by NO and NH3. Yang et al. [51] obtained similar results by using GGA approximation and hybrid functional calculation of B3LYP. SO2 was more likely to combine with ZCuOH in the eight-membered ring. In addition, they also found that the presence of water and oxygen in the humid environment would accelerate the sulfurization of Z2Cu in the six-membered ring. 3.3.2 Alkali metal poisoning Unlike sulfur poisoning, alkali metal poisoning and alkaline earth metal poisoning are more likely to occur on oxide catalysts. DFT calculation showed that the neutralization exotherm of alkali metals and Brønsted acid sites was greater than the adsorption exotherm of NH3, so alkali metal easily reacted with Brønsted acid on the surface of the catalyst. The number of Brønsted acid sites is reduced and the acidity was weakened, so the adsorption capacity of NH3 was also greatly reduced. At the same time, it also affected the reduction performance of the catalyst. This is the main reason for the alkali metal poisoning of the vanadium-based oxide SCR catalyst [75]. In fact, the alkali metal poisoning mechanism of the SCR catalyst is not simple. For example, for the low-temperature SCR catalyst Mn/TiO2, the effects of alkali metal K, Na and alkaline earth metal Ca are not the same [76]. K will obviously cause more serious deactivation. On the one hand, the deposition of potassium ions will reduce the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst. On the other hand, it will weaken the adsorption of NH3 on the Lewis acid site, which is the main active site on the oxide catalyst. The decrease of Lewis acid site activity directly leads to the decrease of catalyst performance, which has been confirmed by DFT calculation [77]. In order to investigate the deactivation mechanism of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst induced by alkali metals, Peng et al. [78] used K atom as the probe to drop on the catalyst surface. Their calculations chose Material Studio model DMol3 module, PBE exchange relevant functional and polarization function with the double-number rail base group (DNP). They respectively established TiO2, V2O5 / TiO2, and comparing the surface model of WO3/TiO2, through calculating the density of states to get the optimization model of the electronic structure and reduction performance, PDOS analysis as shown in Fig. 17 . According to the band gap formed at the top of the valence band and the bottom of the conduction band, the band gap of V2O5/TiO2 was obviously widened after doping K element, while the band gap of WO3/TiO2 basically remained unchanged. The results showed that the alkaline atoms mainly affected the V species of the active site, but had little effect on the oxides of W. Therefore, the anti-alkali metal poisoning ability of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 can be improved by modifying doped CeO2 to reduce the content of V. For calcium poisoning of vanadium-based catalysts, the doping of calcium reduces the acidity and reducibility of the catalyst. However, if modified with Ce, the performance of the catalyst can be improved to a certain extent. Moreover, calcium doping will improve the sulfur resistance of the catalysts [79]. Based on the above studies, it can be explained that DFT calculation is helpful for us to better obtain the change of micro information such as energy state density of active site, electron structure and charge density before and after alkali metal poisoning of catalyst, so as to explain the mechanism of alkali metal poisoning and the improvement mechanism of anti-poisoning ability of catalyst from molecular and atomic level, which would provide new mentality for the development and improvement of catalysts, related research such as copper modified manganese oxide catalysts show better low temperature activity and sulfur resistance [80], Ce-modified Mn-based catalysts show better sulfur resistance [81], and some interesting studies, such as SO2 can significantly improve the performance of Pb poisoned vanadium based catalysts [82]. We would also specifically introduce the application of DFT in catalyst modification research later. All in all, in the aspect of the study of catalyst poisoning mechanism, whether it is sulfur poisoning of zeolite or alkali metal poisoning of oxide, DFT is a method worth using in the process of studying poisoning mechanism. 3.4 Hydrothermal aging mechanisms Due to the narrow catalytic temperature range of V2O5-WO3 (MoO3)/TiO2 (300–400 °C) only has a high catalytic efficiency and vanadium toxicity and other defects, more attention has turned to the wide catalytic temperature range of copper-exchange zeolite catalyst. Compared with zeolite structures such as ZSM-5 and BEA, the CHA structure copper-exchange zeolite catalyst is a major breakthrough in the development of SCR technology: it has a wide catalytic temperature window, and has high hydrothermal stability and catalytic activity. But because of the power plant flue gas and automotive diesel engine aftertreatment system actively regeneration, SCR catalysts are unavoidably exposed to water thermal aging environment, the presence of H2O molecules on the active sites on zeolites and zeolite skeleton on the fragile structure produces a certain amount of damage, leading to a zeolite catalyst hydrothermal deactivation [83], hydrothermal stability has become a zeolite is applied to the production practice of copper is an important standard. The synthesis methods of copper zeolite with CHA structure include ion exchange method, impregnation method, one-pot method, etc. Different synthesis methods and material ratio would have an impact on the load of copper, which is directly related to the hydrothermal stability of zeolite [4,84]. On the other hand, the change of Si/Al ratio is directly related to the physical and chemical structure, acidity and properties of copper species of copper zeolites, so the Si/Al ratio is also an important factor affecting the hydrothermal stability of copper zeolites [85]. Taking Cu-SSZ-13 as an example, there are abundant experimental results on its hydrothermal stability. The deactivation of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst caused by hydrothermal aging is caused by the collapse of zeolites skeleton caused by dealuminization and the loss of activity caused by the transformation of active copper species to copper oxide clusters. Serious dealuminization would not occur below 600 ℃, but would be intensified at higher temperatures, and Al removed from the skeleton would even interact with copper oxide clusters, which is an important cause of skeleton collapse, mainly occurring in zeolites with high copper content and high Si/Al ratio [83]. Nishitoba et al. [86] used different synthetic materials to synthesize CHA catalysts with different aluminum distribution characteristics. Through experimental characterization, they confirmed the aluminum distribution state in the catalyst and the influence on hydrothermal stability, and tried to develop a new zeolite with controllable skeleton atom distribution. As for the inactivation of the copper active site, Daya et al. [87] demonstrated that the copper site was affected by aging time and aging temperature by establishing a reaction kinetics model. However, there are still some difficulties in the study of the hydrothermal stability. For example, the copper oxide clusters generated by the aging of copper sites are located in the pore channels of the zeolite. Some clusters are too small to be observed by experimental means, and their size and location are difficult to be determined. Some researchers have explored ways to improve the hydrothermal stability of copper zeolites by introducing other elements, but to understand the reasons for the improvement of the hydrothermal stability of copper zeolites at the atomic level cannot be accomplished by experimental means alone, which reflects the necessity of quantum chemical calculation. Using DFT to study the hydrothermal stability of zeolites can explain the changes of active sites and carrier skeleton of catalysts during hydrothermal aging from the molecular and atomic levels. Combined with the characterization of new and old catalysts by experimental methods, we can find out the specific mechanism of deactivation and explain the changes caused by the introduction of some elements from the perspective of atomic interaction. Therefore, the elemental ratio can be better controlled and the synthesis method can be improved when the new type catalyst with high hydrothermal stability is synthesized. Song et al. [88] characterized SSZ-13 catalysts with different Si/Al ratio, copper loading, they found dealuminization and copper ion detachment occurred after hydrothermal aging. The separation of ZCuOH site during hydrothermal aging was also observed but Z2Cusite remained active. Therefore, it is necessary to further explore the separation of copper ions. DFT calculations based on CP2K code, PBE exchange related functional got hydrolyzed energy mapping of these two structures, as shown in Fig. 18 and Fig. 19 (All DFT calculations employed a mixed Gaussian and planewave basis sets. The generalized gradient approximation exchange-correlation functional of Perdew, Burke, and Enzerhof (PBE) was used). The highest Gibbs free energy barrier of ZCuOH hydrolysis in the eight-member ring is 155 kJ/mol, so it is assumed that Cu(OH)2 migration and agglomeration form CuO x cluster, and the diffusion of CuO x cluster may lead to the cavity blockage of SSZ-13, which is an important cause of structural instability during the hydrothermal aging process. When Z2Cu in the six-member ring is hydrolyzed, according to the simulation results, the first Cu-OH formation needs to overcome the 92 kJ/mol energy barrier, and the second Cu-OH formation needs to overcome the 233 kJ/mol energy barrier, which indicates that the hydrothermal stability of Z2Cu in the six-member ring is much higher than that of ZCuOH in the eight-member ring. Based on the above DFT calculation, the influence mechanism of hydrothermal aging on SSZ-13 has been understood at the atomic level. In the subsequent catalyst design, we can try to improve the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst by changing the morphology of the dropped copper species. Cu-SSZ-13 water thermal stability would be affected by other factors, Wang et al. [89] studied the influence of alkali metal elements on the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13. Cu-SSZ-13 with different alkali metal loads was characterized by H2-TPR, XRD, DRIFT and other methods under different hydrothermal aging temperatures. It was found that the high load of alkali metals weakened the acidity of the zeolite, and the copper active site was transformed into copper oxide and even the CHA framework collapsed, which resulted in the obvious deactivation of the catalyst. Bond energy calculation found that the bond energy of K + and catalyst bonding is the largest, considering that the diameter of K + in the hydration form is very small, these factors well explain the reason that K + strongly weakened the hydrothermal stability of zeolite. Therefore, attention should be paid to the influence of K + and hydrothermal temperature on the hydrothermal stability in practical application, so as to prevent the hydrothermal aging and deactivation of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst (All calculations were carried out with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA)-Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional). Experimental research and characterization can be used to identify element content and group types, and explain the reasons for the change of hydrothermal stability of catalysts from a macro level, such as the reason for the change of hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13 caused by alkali metals and alkaline earth metals [90]. 4 Catalysts modification and design based on dft Based on the above-mentioned research aspects, the performance evaluation indicators of SCR catalysts include catalytic activity, temperature window range, low temperature performance, anti-poisoning performance and hydrothermal aging resistance. The synthesis of catalysts often has problems such as long synthesis cycles and cumbersome synthesis methods. The development of new catalysts requires a lot of manpower and material resources. The exploration of new synthesis methods and the use of new materials are expensive and difficult to put into use quickly. Under the circumstances, the modification of the catalyst is an effective means to improve the comprehensive performance of the existing catalyst. Metal modification is the most commonly used catalyst modification method. For zeolite catalysts, the modification can also be achieved by introducing mesopores into the zeolite. Through modification, the surface acidity of the catalyst can be changed, and the number and distribution of surface active sites can be affected. For zeolite catalysts, it can also change the pore structure and improve the anti-coking ability [91]. Studying the effect of modification on catalyst performance can be used to guide the search for new modification methods and new preparation schemes, which greatly broadens the path to improve catalyst performance. Commonly used experimental methods such as infrared spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction can be used to analyze the surface structure, crystal structure, and search for surface active sites of catalysts. Combined with the advantages of DFT in structure optimization, analysis of vibration frequency and energy changes, it can be supplemented in experiments, DFT is also applied in the research of catalyst modification on the ion position of zeolite and the interaction between metal ions and molecular framework. Some common metal elements used for modification include cobalt, cerium, zirconium, and some transition metals, etc. Doping with one or more different elements can improve the performance of the catalyst from various aspects. DFT is used to analyze from the micro level. It can reveal the reason why the catalyst performance is improved by the introduction of new elements, and provide new solutions and ways for the further improvement of the comprehensive performance of the catalyst. The following would introduce the application of DFT in catalyst modification from the aspects of improving the surface and internal structure, adsorption capacity, SCR reaction activity and anti-poisoning ability of the catalyst through modification. Catalyst modification can change the surface structure of the catalyst, thereby changing the ability of the catalyst to adsorb and act on gas molecules and improving its performance. This is particularly obvious in oxide catalysts. The modification of oxide catalysts is beneficial to the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. The existence of oxygen vacancies is conducive to the adsorption and decomposition of oxygen, that is, it increases the amount of surface active oxygen, which has an impact on the adsorption of NO and NH3. For example, Ce-doping can promote the adsorption of no on the surface of γ-Al2O3 (1 1 0), but it is not conducive to the adsorption of NH3. Zr-doping can promote the adsorption of no and NH3 on the surface of γ-Al2O3 (1 1 0). These conclusions can be verified by DFT calculation results [92]. The changes in the catalyst surface structure and adsorption performance would directly affect the SCR performance of the catalyst. DFT can be used to intuitively obtain the changes in the catalyst surface structure caused by the modification. The SCR performance of manganese doped CeO2-WO3 catalyst was studied by Peng et al. [93] combined with experimental method and DFT calculation method. They prepared a manganese-containing catalyst and a manganese-free catalyst by a combined precipitation method. The Fourier transform infrared diffuse reflectance spectrometer was used to test the in-situ DRIFT spectrum, and the X-ray diffractometer was used to analyze the crystal structure. The experimental results show that the incorporation of manganese increases the conversion rate of NO x at low temperature. This is due to the incorporation of manganese brings more Brønsted acid sites and higher reducibility; combined with DFT calculations, the incorporation of manganese reduces the formation energy of oxygen vacancies makes it easier to adsorb NH3, and the catalytic activity of the catalyst is improved (Double-numerical plus polarization functions and GGA-PBE were used in all calculations using the Material Studio Modeling Dmol3 package). Zhang et al. [94] analyzed the effect of F modification on the surface characteristics of the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst through DFT calculation and PL spectroscopy, thereby explaining the reason for the improvement of its SCR performance. Their calculations show that the F modification would form oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst, and the electrons on the oxygen vacancies are easily captured by V atoms to form reduced V species, which are confirmed by XPS, O2-TPD, and EPR. These reduced V species eventually become active sites for the formation of superoxide ions and promote the oxidation of NO to facilitate the occurrence of SCR reactions. Fig. 20 shows the charge density diagram of the formation of oxygen vacancies on the F-modified TiO2 support and the interaction with V atoms. It can be clearly found that the area of ​​the oxygen vacancy electron defect of the VTiF catalyst is larger than that of the TiF-Ov support, and the charge density of oxygen atoms around the oxygen vacancies of the VTiF catalyst is also greatly reduced, that is, the V species captured the electrons on the oxygen vacancies, which provides key information for further explaining the reasons for the improved performance of the catalyst (Double-numerical-quality basis set with polarization functions (DNP) and GGA-PBE were used for all calculations using Material Studio 5.5 modeling DMol3). Similar studies include the improved catalytic activity of Mn-modified CeO2–WO3 catalysts [93], etc. Not limited to the surface structure, we can also use DFT to study the changes in the internal space structure and acidic sites of the catalyst caused by the modification. This is more commonly used in zeolite catalysts, such as Ti modified SSZ-13. When adsorbing water molecules, the hydrolysis forms two independent Brønsted acid sites, which can serve as potential catalytic sites [95]. These studies have deepened the understanding of the properties of zeolites and provided help to improve their performance. The modification causes the structural characteristics of the catalyst to change, and the mechanism of the SCR reaction changes accordingly. We can also use DFT to study the mechanism changes caused by the modification. For example, Gao et al. [96] modified Zr0. 05Mn0. 95Cr2O4 with Zr, the surface Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites of the Zr0. 05Mn0. 95Cr2O4 catalyst were 3.5 times higher than that of MnCr2O4. At the same time, various nitrates were detected in the SCR reaction. This is beneficial for SCR activity below 250 °C. Further DFT calculations showed that the adsorption energy of NH3, NH2, NO and NO2 was greatly reduced after Zr modification, and the formation energy barrier of NH2 and NO2 was also significantly reduced, which was very conducive to the formation of SCR reaction intermediate products. These studies explain the reasons for the improved performance of the catalyst from the perspective of adsorption and mechanism. Fig. 21 shows a comparison diagram of the adsorption structure and adsorption energy of NH2 groups before and after Zr modification (Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhoff (PBE) functional in generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used to calculate the exchange-correlation potential using Materials Studio 2017 modeling DMol3). Based on DFT to study the effect of modification on the anti-poisoning ability of the catalyst, some results have also been obtained. Because of its relatively low price, Ce can improve the performance of the catalyst in various aspects. It is a commonly used modification element and has received extensive attention and research [97]. Here, we take the modification of Ce to improve the toxicity of the catalyst as an example. First of all, in terms of sulfur resistance, Wei et al. [81] used DFT and DRIFT methods to investigate the sulfur resistance mechanism of cerium-modified manganese-based catalysts that undergo SCR reactions at low temperatures. According to the energy convergence test, the unit cell with the lowest energy of Mn3O4 was obtained, and the TiO2 carrier model was reconstructed; In DFT calculation, the exchange-related functional PW91 and the dual-value orbit basis set with polarization function (DNP) are selected for structural optimization and energy calculation. According to the results of DRIFT and DFT, SO2 is first adsorbed on L acid site to form sulfate, which hinders the adsorption process of NH3 in SCR reaction, while the deactivation of Brønsted acid site is due to the consumption of NH4 +. After adding the cerium element to modify, SO2 would first adsorb on the cerium atom to form sulfate, which weakens the effect of SO2 on the L acid site and the Brønsted acid site, and the sulfate formed on the cerium surface would further promote the new Brønsted acid site Appears, thus speeding up the SCR reaction process at low temperature and greatly weakening the phenomenon of sulfur poisoning. Research on improving the resistance to alkali metals, such as Peng et al. [98], combined experimental methods and DFT theoretical calculations, to explore the mechanism of alkali metal resistance of cerium-improved MNO x /TiO2 catalysts. According to the comparison of the stability of the TiO2 crystal plane, the (0 0 1) plane was selected to construct the super-large unit cell of Ti24O48, and DFT + U calculation method was used for structural optimization and energy analysis. The mechanism of potassium poisoning is the weakening of the acidity of the catalyst surface and the loss of reducing ability caused by alkali metals. The formation of stable nitrate and nitrite would also cause the deactivation of the catalyst; after cerium modification, cerium brings a new L acid site for NH3 adsorption, and this acid site is less affected by alkali metals. At the same time, the 4f orbital of the cerium atom is almost unaffected on the poisoned surface, that is, it still maintains a relatively high reducing power for the NH3 activation reaction. After the addition of cerium, stable and inactive nitrate species would not accumulate on the surface of the catalyst, while active nitrate species would continue to be generated; the above three aspects can explain the effect of cerium modification to overcome alkali metal poisoning. The mechanism is shown in Fig. 22 . For some other elements such as chromium, nickel, cobalt, selenium, tin, etc. are also commonly used for modification, we often use DFT to simulate the modification of different elements, which reduces a lot of experimental complexity to a certain extent and improves research Efficiency, this is a major advantage of DFT when looking for elements suitable for modification, which provides a direction and idea for the development and design of catalysts [99]. For example, Wei et al. [100] also used DFT to study their improvement on the sulfur resistance of MNO2 (1 0 0). They used the generalized gradient approximation exchange correlation functional PBE, and the dual-value orbital basis set calculated the adsorption energy of these five atoms at different manganese sites in MNO2. Based on the analysis of the adsorption and dissociation of NH3, it is known that the activity of the acid site directly determines the conversion rate of NO; ​​the electronic density of states analysis shows that the incorporation of chromium, nickel, and cobalt can enhance the strength of the L acid site. Selenium and tin would weaken it. As far as sulfur resistance is concerned, modification of selenium and tin can improve sulfur resistance; on the whole, chromium is the most potential modification element. Lyu et al. [101] used DFT to study the modification of the transition metal manganese, titanium, chromium and nickel on the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. Based on certain experimental data, a (2 × 2) α-Fe2O3 periodic plane model with 9 atomic layers is first established; PBE exchange correlation functional with generalized gradient approximation are used, pseudopotentials are used to describe the interaction between valence electrons and ion nuclei, and extend the electron wave function with a plane wave basis set with a spin polarization function and 400 eV pure energy. The simulation calculated the formation energy of oxygen vacancies and the adsorption of NH3 and O2 on the surface of the catalyst. It was found that these four elements can be modified on the top layer of the model and would change the surface structure and properties of the catalyst. The incorporation of manganese, chromium and nickel would decrease the formation energy of oxygen vacancies; compared with chromium and nickel, the incorporation of manganese and titanium would enhance the adsorption of NH3 and O2, which makes the surface acidity of Fe2O3 increase, and NO is more easily oxidized to NO2, which is conducive to the rapid SCR reaction. Therefore, it is concluded that chromium and nickel are not suitable for the modification of α-Fe2O3, and manganese is the most suitable element for modification. In view of the above research results, the use of DFT to find suitable modifying elements avoids the complexity of multiple experiments and can greatly save time and cost. Since the Zn-containing compound is significantly more stable than the Cu compound, especially some dimers, considering the influence of the silicon-to-aluminum ratio, [Zn-OH]-Z and [Cu-O-Zn]a are the main structure that inhibits the collapse of the CHA framework, which is the main reason why Zn improves the hydrothermal aging resistance of Cu-SSZ-13. It has been successfully improved to a certain extent. The hydrothermal aging mechanism of copper zeolite is described. It lays the foundation for improving the hydrothermal stability through catalyst modification and then proposing new catalyst synthesis schemes. The purpose of our research on catalyst modification is to find a catalyst with higher catalytic activity, wider catalytic temperature window, stronger anti-toxic performance, and better hydrothermal aging performance. We understand the relevant information of the catalyst from the atomic and molecular level, and finally become the catalyst. The synthesis of DFT provides guidance and direction, and DFT would play an increasingly important role in this process. 5 Summary and outlook As a typical research method in quantum mechanics, DFT theoretical method has brought great convenience to the research of SCR catalysts and is a powerful tool. The current use of DFT has included: determining the location and distribution of active sites on the catalyst surface; calculating the adsorption energy of the reaction and the formation energy of oxygen vacancies to study the adsorption mechanism of reactant gasses NH3 and NO x ; calculating the activation energy of the elementary reaction to determine the speed control step of the entire reaction; determines the path of the chemical reaction by calculating the intermediate species and transition state energy of the reaction; explains the SCR reaction mechanism of different catalysts; studies the poisoning mechanism and hydrothermal aging mechanism of the catalyst; and studies the catalyst The modification proposed new catalyst design methods and so on. In the research of SCR reaction, theoretical calculation of DFT is an auxiliary tool, but it is not limited to auxiliary function. It can obtain a lot of information on the micro-level of the catalyst. Experimental characterization methods such as XRD, DRIFT, NH3-TPD, etc. can observe some phenomena in the process of SCR reaction, and then explain these phenomena. The introduction of DFT calculations can once again verify these phenomena theoretically, making them more reliable, and calculations are also easier to reveal the underlying causes of these phenomena from the microscopic atomic level, that is, to deepen the understanding of the atomic level of the SCR reaction process. DFT can also optimize geometric configuration, calculate single-point energy, predict potential barriers and reaction paths, describe bonding characteristics and even perform spectral analysis. Finally, this information can be used for the development and preparation of new high-performance catalysts, reducing time and economic costs, and realizing practical value. Another advantage of DFT is that the method is a universal method and would not be restricted by the research object and the research process. Regardless of whether it is for oxide catalysts or zeolite catalysts, whether it is the adsorption process of a chemical reaction, the reaction process, or even the aging and poisoning process of the catalyst, a series of useful information can be obtained by DFT in various studies similar to those mentioned above. At the same time, DFT realizes the combination of kinetic calculations and experimental spectroscopy analysis, which is more in-depth in theoretical calculations and supplements and explains the experimental data. But DFT also has its shortcomings. In terms of model construction, saturation of the boundary of the cluster model with hydrogen atoms would cause deviations from the actual structure. The calculation accuracy of the embedded calculation method ONIOM is too dependent on the choice of high-precision layers, and the periodic model is not suitable for large unit cell objects. In terms of basis set selection, hybrid functionals have higher calculation accuracy than plane wave basis sets, but the calculation is more expensive [103]. Some systems such as zeolites have more complex spatial structures, resulting in huge calculations, and sometimes the accuracy of calculation results is difficult to verify. The calculation results of some special systems are very dependent on the selection of calculation methods. Based on the above advantages and disadvantages, here are some suggestions for calculating using DFT. When constructing the model, it is necessary to fully consider the research object and research content for selection. A reasonable structure model (cluster model, embedded model, periodic structure model, etc.) is the basis of calculation and directly determines the quality of the calculation result. According to the selection of research objects, such as cluster models are mostly suitable for oxide systems, and porous zeolite systems are more suitable for periodic models; according to research content, such as periodic models are more suitable for the study of catalyst surface properties, which are close to the actual surface condition of the catalyst and easier to compare with the experimental results. Second, pay attention to the selection of calculation methods and the setting of calculation parameters. It is necessary to make corresponding changes for different research objects and research processes. For example, the GGA approximation would be significantly larger when calculating the reaction energy involved in NO x . In this case, hybridization is used. The functional exchange correlation function would be more accurate. Particular attention should be paid to some special structures and systems. If the method is not suitable, it would inevitably lead to a large calculation error, and it is naturally difficult to achieve mutual comparison with experimental results. Even in some cases, it is still necessary to use different methods to calculate the same process of the same object. The choice of calculation method must not be static, but a better method can always be found. Finally, in the actual calculation, the calculation accuracy and the time and money cost of the calculation should be comprehensively considered. In some cases, it is necessary to simplify the research process and make a certain approximate treatment. With the continuous deepening of research, more accurate calculation models and calculation methods can be found for many materials and systems, and our calculation results would be more accurate, which has greater reference significance. The development of calculation software and calculation methods is also endless. Although we have many mature calculation tools and classic calculation methods, there are always situations where the calculation accuracy is too low and the application is limited. We still need to compare the existing calculations. Methods are improved and new calculation models and methods are created based on existing theories. Difficulties and opportunities coexist. In the future SCR field research, DFT would still play a role in various aspects. In order to explain the catalytic reaction mechanism and guide the synthesis of catalysts, DFT itself would also be further developed and improved. coredata.dc:description: In recent years, molecular simulation methods, especially density functional theory (DFT), have attracted much attention and been widely used to study the SCR reaction theoretically and microscopically. This review discusses the application of DFT in SCR research from the aspects of surface adsorption, active site characteristics, reaction mechanism, poisoning mechanism, and hydrothermal aging mechanism to illustrate the status of quantum chemical computing in this field. The gas adsorption includes the adsorption of nitrogen oxides, ammonia, and their co-adsorption. The site and mechanism include the properties of different active sites, intermediate species analysis, and reaction mechanism research. The poisoning includes related research on sulfur poisoning and alkali metal poisoning. The hydrothermal aging includes research on dealumination and loss of active sites. It is demonstrated that the catalysts can be improved and rationally designed based on quantum chemistry calculations. Finally, the application of DFT in this field is evaluated, hoping to provide good suggestions for DFT calculations to further understand the more complicated reaction mechanisms and optimally design the SCR catalysts.
